docs.lead_paragraph: In a kitchen on 86th Avenue in Briarwood, Queens, Istam Kaziyeva, a 67-year-old Bukharian Jewish woman from Tashkent, Uzbekistan, rolls a stiff, tan ball of dough into a flat circle about the size of a medium pizza. She then carefully places the bread over the rounded bottom of a wok turned upside down and slides it into her natural gas oven to bake. Until four years ago, Mrs. Kaziyeva made this nontoki bread in a brick tandoori oven in the backyard of the family home in Central Asia. In 1993 the family sold the house that Mrs. Kaziyeva's husband, Iliya Kaziyev, had built, gave away the furniture and moved with their family, then 14 members, to Queens.
docs.abstract: 40,000 Bukharian Jews who have settled in Rego Park, Forest Hills and Briarwood, Queens, are facing possible loss of health care benefits because of changes in welfare and immigration laws; Istam and Iliya Kaziyeva of Briarwood were told they have 10 months to become citizens or risk losing Medicaid benefits; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: CONNECTICUT is coming late to the table of deregulation concerning the electric utility industry within its borders. But, though the issue may not spark wild enthusiasm among most state residents, legislation now under consideration could have a profound impact on consumers' wallets, as well as the state's environmental quality. Electric rates in the state are 35 percent higher than the national average. The question is whether restructuring of the industry will wind up costing the customer more or less than the current system. It depends entirely on the details of legislation now under consideration in the state.

headline.main: Will Electric Bills Go Up or Down?

docs.abstract: Electric rates in Connecticut are 35 percent higher than national average; deregulation legislation now under consideration could have profound impact on consumers' electric bills; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pete Kompkoff and the other villagers of Chenega know perfectly well that when the Exxon Valdez hemorrhaged oil onto their shores, it was the crew that was at fault, and not the ship. But they are not about to sit back silently in the coming weeks as the Exxon Corporation seeks permission in Federal District Court here for the tanker, renamed the Mediterranean, to return to Prince William Sound, where she unleashed one of the worst environmental disasters.

headline.main: Alaska Residents Oppose Exxon's Effort to Bring Back the Valdez
headline.kicker: A Tanker Hauling Memories Is Shunned

docs.abstract: Exxon Corp is seeking court permission for the tanker Exxon Valdez, since renamed, to return to Prince William Sound in Alaska, where in 1989 she struck reef and caused nation's worst oil spill; residents of Chenega, Alaska, angry that Exxon Corp is still appealing financial penalties imposed by jury, are mounting campaign to prevent tanker's return; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Desperate for his mother to get a job and move off welfare before being pushed, Raymond Miller, 14, paces in a tiny apartment near the screeching El train, and calls her to the kitchen table. ''Let's get started,'' says the eighth grader, opening a textbook from his mother's class on becoming a nurse's aide. ''We're going to review Chapter 3.''

headline.main: Uncertain Future, on Their Own, Awaits

docs.abstract: Six Welfare Lives: The Changing Equation, first article in series on how new Federal law reshaping world of welfare will effect six diverse poor families who survive on Government checks; under new law, cash payments to poor families will be limited to five years; also, 25 percent of state's welfare recipients must be working or involved in training programs this year, and 50 percent by year 2002; examination of lives of six poor families reveals strikingly diverse backgrounds and abilities, perspectives and prospects; photos (L)

keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: A TRIP to the supermarket late one evening became a nightmare for June Neal, director of communications for the state Department of Consumer Protection. After Ms. Neal finished her shopping, she headed for the one checkout lane that was open. A line formed behind her as the clerk checked out groceries with the efficiency of a sleepwalker. Then the clerk picked up a telephone and began a conversation with her boyfriend. Finally, the store manager came by and told the clerk to hang up the phone and get back to work. The clerk swore at her boss, slammed the phone down and walked off. ''It really bothered me, because my son was with me,'' Ms. Neal said. ''I don't like him to see an adult swearing and acting like that.''

headline.main: It's a Service Economy, But Where's the Service?

docs.abstract: Connecticut's economy draws much of its strength from service-related businesses, but stories abound about consumers being treated poorly; Consumer Protection Dept says problems that cause consumers most aggravation involve retailers, home improvement businesses and direct mail and telemarketing companies; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Investing in preventive care is a cornerstone of our business because of the tremendous returns it provides. . . . It keeps health care costs low by preventing serious illness and promoting a healthy lifestyle.'' -- U.S. Healthcare annual report ''PREVENTION saves money'' has become a refrain of managed care, repeated in ads and by H.M.O. executives so often that it has taken on the aura of truth.
docs.abstract: Good preventive care that is big drawing card for health maintenance organizations is often not cost-effective in long run, since early diagnosis of conditions like hypertension, high cholesterol and HIV is often followed by lifetime of costly treatment; photo; even smoking cessation can be costly, in strictly financial terms, since reformed smokers will live longer; HMOs are nevertheless likely to improve wellness care, because it gives them good image and meets employers' demands (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Ridgewood psychologist convicted of swindling nearly $3 million from health insurance companies was sentenced yesterday to five and a half years in prison. The psychologist, Dr. Carl Lichtman, 50, who masterminded a scheme involving at least 17 accomplices, was also ordered to pay $2.8 million in restitution to the insurance companies, according to his lawyer, Brian Neary.
docs.abstract: Dr Carl Lichtman, 50-year-old Ridgewood, NJ, psychologist convicted of swindling nearly $3 million from health insurance companies, is sentenced to five-and-one-half years in prison; is also ordered to pay $2.8 million in restitution to insurance companies; he masterminded scheme involving at least 17 accomplices (S) (New Jersey Daily Briefing)

docs.lead_paragraph: Children infected with the virus that causes AIDS became eligible today to receive a potent new class of drugs that has sharply reduced the virus's level in adults. The Food and Drug Administration approved for use by children two anti-AIDS drugs known as protease inhibitors that are used alone, or in combination with other drugs, to combat the viral infection. In studies on adults, the combination therapy has been highly effective.

headline.main: AIDS Drug Is Approved As Therapy For Children

docs.abstract: FDA approves use by children of two anti-AIDS drugs, protease inhibitors, that have sharply reduced level of virus in adults; Viracept is sold by Agouron Pharmaceuticals and Norvir by Abbott Laboratories (S)
docs.snippet: Children infected with the virus that causes AIDS became eligible today to receive a potent new class of drugs that has sharply reduced the virus's level in adults.    The Food and Drug Administration approved for use by children two anti-AIDS drugs...

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Dwight Locke Wilbur, a prominent San Francisco gastroenterologist and past president of the American Medical Association, who helped overcome the organization's aversion to Medicare as ''socialized medicine,'' died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 93. In the 1960's, when Dr. Wilbur rose to leadership in the A.M.A., his profession, like the rest of the nation, was deeply divided over crucial issues. Medical insurance for the country's elderly was one of them, and he was considered a moderate in the A.M.A.'s determined struggle against Government encroachment in medical care.

headline.main: Dwight L. Wilbur, 93, President Of A.M.A. Who Aided Medicare

docs.abstract: Dr Dwight Locke Wilbur, prominent San Francisco gastroenterologist and past president of American Medical Assn who helped overcome AMA's aversion to Medicare as 'socialized medicine,' dies at 93 (M)
